title: Elysium
introduction: Elysium, also known as the Elysian Fields, is a conception of the afterlife in Greek mythology where heroes and virtuous individuals are granted eternal happiness. Initially reserved for mortals related to the gods and heroes, Elysium evolved to include those chosen by the gods, the righteous, and the heroic, allowing them to indulge in whatever they had enjoyed in life.
mythicHistory:
In Homer's writings, Elysium is described as a land of perfect happiness located at the end of the Earth, on the banks of the river Oceanus. This paradise was initially separated from the Greek underworld, the realm of Hades, and only mortals related to the gods and other heroes could be admitted past the river Styx.

The poet Hesiod referred to Elysium as the "Isles of the Blessed," located in the western ocean at the end of the Earth. This conception depicted Elysium as a place where the righteous and heroic could enjoy a blessed and happy afterlife, indulging in whatever they had enjoyed in life.

Over time, the idea of who could enter Elysium expanded to include those chosen by the gods, the righteous, and the heroic. This evolution reflects a broader understanding of virtue and reward in the afterlife within Greek religious and philosophical thought.
